title: Fears for press freedom ahead of Polish elections as populists plan 're-polanisation' of foreign media
text:
At the same time, a Law and Justice overhaul of the judicial system has prompted yet further allegations that it is chipping away at the pillars of democracy, while bringing the country into a heated conflict with the European Union. Earlier this week, Brussels announced that it was taking to Poland to court over a new disciplinary regime for judges that allegedly threatens their independence; a move slammed by the Polish government as a “political act”.

This too has increased fears in Brussels that Poland is now following in the footsteps of Hungary. The Hungarian government has challenged what it regards as the orthodoxy of liberal democracy in Europe by promoting the concept of a nation state bound together by traditional Christian values and culture.

But that concept, according to its critics, also has little time or tolerance for anything or anybody that questions or fails to conform to it, and as a consequence has helped roll back democracy in the Central European country, they claim.

Yet despite all the fears and misgivings, both at home and abroad, over Law and Justice, the party remains popular in Poland, as the opinion polls attest.

Along with presiding over one of Europe’s most successful economies, Law and Justice has employed a successful “carrot and stick policy”, says Piotr Kaczynski, a political commentator and blogger on Polish affairs. The carrot, in this case, is social spending, while the stick has come in the form of demonising its critics as people who are against Poland.

Lavish social spending programmes and a promise to almost double the minimum wage by 2024 have proved to be a particular hit, and has helped foster the image of Law and Justice amongst its supporters as a party that brings tangible changes to their lives.

Echoing Hungary, Law and Justice has also promised to defend the country’s Christian tradition. Speaking earlier this month Jaroslaw Kaczynski, the party’s leader, claimed an opposition victory would bring to power “those who want simply the radical destruction of the moral and cultural order in our country, with all its fatal consequences”.

While this message in the past was tailored to appeal to the elderly people who make up a significant chunk of Law and Justice voters it now has a resonance with younger voters. A poll published last month in Super Express, a Polish tabloid, indicated that 45 per cent of 18-24-year-olds intend to vote for Law and Justice or a far-Right coalition.

In the pamphlet-strewn office of Law and Justice’s youth wing, 25-year-old Michal Szpadrowski believe the party appeals to the young because it offers an identity to a generation not defined by the struggle against communism.

“We were searching for some new values, some personal identification with our country,” said Mr Szpadrowski. “We were looking for a new identity that we could share with our peers in Europe and one that would make us proud of our country. Law and Justice encourages young people to be proud of their country. Young people feel the government is with them and that they don’t have to feel inferior about their country.”

He also dismisses allegations that Law and Justice is undermining democracy or attacking the free press as unfounded. "No journalist has been arrested and you can broadcast what you want,” he argued.
description: The prospect of Law and Justice winning a second term in office has got Lukasz Lipinski worried.
